{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3352649,"name":"","username":"MichaelRemi","avatar_template":"/letter_avatar_proxy/v4/letter/m/22d042/{size}.png","created_at":"2024-04-04T23:02:12.620Z","cooked":"

Hi,

We want to access the Hall Effect Sensor Data from the NEO motor to track the position of our motor arm. We have the NEO hooked up to a 36:1 planetary gearbox, so we should have high resolution for a full rotation of our output shaft.

We’re controlling the motor by sending PWM signals through an ESP-32 coded in C++. How do we read hall sensor data

I’ve looked through the RevLib C++ Library, but it’s unclear which encoder is the hall sensor and which functions will give us the info we need.

docs.revrobotics.com

REVLib Information | SPARK MAX

MichaelRemi:

We’re controlling the motor by sending PWM signals through an ESP-32 coded in C++.

Is this for FRC? If so, doing that is not legal. Any PWM signals controlling motors must be generated by the RoboRIO directly. Is there a reason you’re not using CAN for control, since it’s required to get the encoder value anyway?

MichaelRemi:

I’ve looked through the RevLib C++ Library, but it’s unclear which encoder is the hall sensor and which functions will give us the info we need.

You want to call CANSparkMax::GetEncoder(SparkRelativeEncoder::kHallSensor, 42) (I think 42 is correct here.

Not for FRC, this is a sister thread to

How to change motor speed in one revolution - NEO with SparkMax Programming
The RevLib C++ library is for if you’re controlling the motor controller over CAN, and is primarily supported for the FIRST Robotics competition. I would be surprised if you could even make it work with an ESP32 (I could be misunderstanding something here about your approach). The Rev docs all assume you’re doing FRC. I provided some resource further up in the thread about reading the hall effect sensor, but it will be a highly custom solution, and you won’t be able to rely on Rev example code. …
